title: How to Wash Yeast

steps.headline: Boil 1 gallon (3.8 L) of water for 15 minutes, then let it cool.
steps.description: You need to boil the water first to sanitize it. If you don’t do this, then you risk contaminating your brew with harmful bacteria that may be in the water. Once you’ve boiled the water, set it aside so that it can cool off to room temperature. While the water is cooling, work on harvesting the yeast from the fermenter. This will help you save some time. The exact temperature of the water doesn't matter as long as it's roughly the same as the temperature of the room that you're working in. Use this method if you want to remove solids and yeast from the previous beer batch.

steps.headline: Pour the beer out of the fermenter to expose the yeast.
steps.description: You can also siphon the beer out instead, then pour it into another container. Be sure to leave a small amount of beer in the fermenter, however; this will help loosen the yeast "cake" at the bottom of the fermenter. Replace the airlock on the fermenter and seal the container you poured the beer into tightly. Sterilize the container that you're pouring the beer into with hot, boiling water. Let it air dry before pouring the beer in.

steps.headline: Swirl the yeast to loosen it, then pour it into a sanitized container.
steps.description: Close the airlock on the fermenter, then swirl it to mix the beer into the yeast cake at the bottom. Open the airlock and pour the liquid into a clean, sanitized 1 US gal (3.8 L) container. The beer-and-yeast liquid is also known as a "slurry." A glass flask, jar, or 1 US gal (3.8 L) carboy will work the best for this.

steps.headline: Pour the boiled water into the yeast, leaving some space at the top.
steps.description: Double-check that the water has cooled to room temperature first; if it's too hot, it will harm the yeast. Leave about 10% of empty space at the top of the container rather than filling the container all the way with water. Pour any leftover water into the sink.

steps.headline: Close the container, shake it for a few minutes, then wait 20 minutes.
steps.description: During this time, the slurry will separate into 3 layers: an upper liquid layer, a middle yeast layer, and a bottom "trub" layer. The trub will appear dark brown while the yeast will look milky-white. The upper liquid layer will be mostly clear, a solution composed mostly of beer and water. Trub is the dark-colored layer at the bottom of your container. It's mostly solids and sediments.

steps.headline: Pour the yeast into a large, sterilized jar, then seal the jar.
steps.description: Clean the jar first with boiling water, then allow it to air dry. Pour the yeast into the jar, leaving the trub behind in the container. Close the jar tightly. The jar should be big enough to hold 1 gallon (3.8 L) of liquid.

steps.headline: Shake the jar, then wait 20 minutes.
steps.description: This last set of shaking and waiting will help separate out any last bits of trub that might have gotten into the yeast. You could always skip this portion, but it 's not recommended.

steps.headline: Pour the yeast into 1-pint (470-mL) jars.
steps.description: Pour the yeast slowly so that you don't get any trub into the jars. If need be, leave some yeast in the larger container. It's better to abandon some yeast rather than harvest trub by mistake. Use as many 1-pint (470-mL) jars as you need in order to store the yeast.

steps.headline: Label the jars, store them in the fridge, and use them within 1 week.
steps.description: Write the name of the yeast on each jar, as well as the date and generation. Keep the jars in the fridge, and try to use the yeast within 1 week. You can wash and reuse yeast 5 times. If the yeast starts to smell or look abnormal, discard it immediately.

steps.headline: Allow the yeast to cool to 36 to 40 °F (2 to 4 °C).
steps.description: Make sure that you keep the yeast at this temperature throughout the entire acid washing process. Do not allow the yeast to drop below 36 °F (2 °C) or rise above 40 °F (4 °C) through the entire washing process. This sounds like it may cold shock the yeast, which is true, but it also helps prevent damage to the yeast cells. This method should only be used as a protective measure against bacteria; it will not remove all contaminants. You still need to sterilize all tools with hot, boiling water.

steps.headline: Transfer your desired amount of yeast into a sterilized glass container.
steps.description: Read your beer recipe to find out how much yeast you should use, then measure out that amount. Place the yeast into a sterilized glass container. Sterilize the glass container ahead of time with boiling water and allow it to air dry. Do not use a towel as this may re-contaminate the container.

steps.headline: Plan to start washing the yeast 2 hours before you pour it.
steps.description: You can pour the yeast back into the fermenter whenever you want to, but it would be best if you do it on the same day. The key here is to start the washing process 2 hours before you add it back in. Decide when you want to "pitch" the yeast, then subtract 2 hours. This is when you need to wash it. Pitching yeast is another term for adding it to the fermenter and wort. The yeast needs to stay at 36 to 40 °F (2 to 4 °C) throughout this time, so plan to work quickly.

steps.headline: Add phosphoric acid gradually until the pH is between 2.0 and 2.5.
steps.description: Use a pH testing kit to test the pH of the yeast first to get an idea of where you stand. Next, add a few drops of food-grade phosphoric acid, and give the slurry a stir. Read the pH again, and add more acid, if needed. Keep adding acid and stirring until the pH falls between 2.0 and 2.5. A little bit of acid can make a huge different, so be patient and add it in a few drops at a time. Be sure to stir the slurry well after each addition that you make. How much food-grade phosphoric acid you need will vary from batch to batch, so just add it in gradually until the pH falls somewhere between 2.0 and 2.5.

steps.headline: Stir the yeast continuously for 60 to 90 minutes.
steps.description: Be sure to maintain both the temperature and pH throughout this process. The yeast needs to stay between 36 and 40 °F (2 and 4 °C) in order for the acid to do its job. You’ll know the acid is working properly if the pH reads between 2.0 and 2.5. A stir plate will make this task either, otherwise you will have to stir it by hand with a sterile utensil. If you're stirring by hand, it might be a good idea to work with a partner so that you can take turns stirring. The temperature shouldn't change too much during this time. As long as it stays below 40 °F (4 °C), you'll be fine. If you have to, switch a fan or air conditioner on.

steps.headline: Pitch the yeast and acid into the fermenter and the wort.
steps.description: Pitching yeast into wort is simply just adding the yeast into the fermenter with the wort. Double-check your recipe as well as the instructions for your kit; sometimes you need to add the yeast into a starter wort first. If you won't be using the yeast right away, pour it into a sterilized container, then store it in the fridge. Make sure that the wort is below 80 °F (27 °C), otherwise you may kill the yeast. If you won't use the yeast right away, pour it into sterilized glass jars, then store them in the fridge for up to 1 week.
